groups.name: Language Usage
groups.description: Guidelines for the appropriate use of language, including gene nomenclature and abbreviations.

requirements.description: Gene abbreviations should be according to HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee.
requirements.reference: The abbreviations of genes are according to HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee.

requirements.description: Gene names and abbreviations should be written in italic font style.
requirements.reference: The abbreviations of genes are written in italic font style (the full names are also written in italic).

requirements.description: Use abbreviations instead of full gene names.
requirements.reference: It is recommended that abbreviations instead of the full name are used.

requirements.description: Human gene names should be written in all capitals.
requirements.reference: Human gene names are written in capitals, for example ALDOA, INS, etc.

requirements.description: For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter is capitalized.
requirements.reference: For orthologs of human genes in other species, only the initial letter is capitalised, for example mouse Aldoa, bovine Ins, etc.

requirements.description: Use 'the ALDOA gene is regulated...' format.
requirements.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: 'the ALDOA gene is regulated...'.

requirements.description: Use 'the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...' format.
requirements.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: 'the rat gene for Aldoa is regulated...'.
requirements.when: When discussing gene regulation in rats.

requirements.reference: The following usages of gene symbols are recommended: 'ALDOA is regulated...'.

requirements.description: Avoid using 'the gene ALDOA is regulated' format.
requirements.reference: The following is not recommended: 'the gene ALDOA is regulated' since it is redundant.
